That means candle is from high pressure region?? Which diamond is high pressure, so candle is high pressure region where it is from, so I am sure all candle is same density which it burns off, so in middle of flame is diamonds is breaking apart into smoke. So that means at lower level, the pressure is very high but at very small space. So, it is not zero, so it is about pressure as depth to amount of resistance. So, candle is from low pressure region, so the resistance is very low, except at micro-space. Which it can burn off, so the fire can't burn normal diamond that you can see because the resistance is too high for fire to be burn off. That means if you look nano-diamond in microscope or smaller, and you use a machine with a twitter or something and you squeeze it, it can crush with your power. So, that mean pressure do depend by density and size of density, not either one alone. So, that means all carbon is diamond like, which diamond has certain pattern. But the amount of resistance, per space, do matter. So, carbon is diamond. But it is about range of amount of resistance per space.

A big problem with diamonds, unless you mine the diamond yourself (and no one is going to do let you do THAT) there is no way to tell if the diamond is not a so called "blood diamond"
DeBeers wants you to think they have that problem licked, but there are so many easy ways to get around the road blocks DeBeers has set up to prevent blood diamonds entering the market that they might as well not be there at all.
On top of that, the entire "tradition" of diamonds being for weddings is made up by the people selling diamonds.. And there is really only one company selling them new. AND because of that the price of a new diamond is GROSSLY inflated
Get her a gemstone to match her favorite color. And if you absolutely have to have a diamond, buy one second hand. It's the only way you can be sure you are not supporting tyrants and slave holders.

it may(keyword) also to an extent has to do with specific heat which is basically the rate at which an object increases in temperature and the specific heat acts as a constant for that material ie water is and always will be the same as any other water the main difference is the mass eq: thermal energy=specific heat*mass*change in temperature since the mass is much lower the same amount of energy input mean the change in temperature will be much greater so it is more likely to evaporate(maybe)

I'm not the man you're looking for.

But I can still try to give you an answer. First of all, the nanodiamonds are not melting, they're burning. The candle flame itself doesn't exceed 1000 - 1500 K, so the 3800 K point is out of the question. As for how it does it, it's transforming the long hydrocarbons in the wax and the oxygen in the air into water and carbon dioxide. This is a chemical reaction which produces net energy, and the excess energy heats up the soot untill it glows yellow.
